Bootstrap production path for mare regolith using the simple mining process.

steps.notes: Extract ilmenite from regolith; yields generated in process.

recipe_def.assumptions: Extraction yields ~0.6 kg ilmenite per 1 kg regolith input; tailings ~0.4 kg.
recipe_def.notes: In-situ ilmenite extraction from regolith; placeholder yields and mass balance.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for ilmenite extraction from regolith

steps.notes: Collection of carbonaceous chondrite regolith from meteorite impact sites. Rare (1-2% of lunar surface) but critical for carbon and volatile extraction. Slower than generic mining due to site prospecting and travel.

recipe_def.notes:
Collection process for carbonaceous regolith from CM/CI chondrite impact sites.
Targets areas with visible dark material enrichment and organic compound signatures.
Rich in carbon (2-5%), water (10%), and volatiles - essential for ISRU operations.

steps.notes: Extract carbon reductant from carbonaceous regolith feedstock.

recipe_def.assumptions: Carbonaceous regolith feedstock available for small-scale carbon recovery.
recipe_def.notes: ISRU extraction route for carbon reductant; drying and sizing steps deferred.

recipe_def.assumptions: Local production path added; replace import placeholder with real production pathway.
recipe_def.notes: Manufacturing recipe for carbon reducing agent using carbon_reductant input.

steps.notes: Single-step carbothermal reduction from ore to iron pig/ingot.

recipe_def.notes: Direct path from iron ore/ilmenite to iron_pig_or_ingot using the iron_smelting_reduction_v0 process.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for iron pig or ingot

steps.notes: Reduce ilmenite/ore with carbon to produce pig iron feedstock.
Refine pig iron and cast billets/slabs for rolling.
Hot roll billets into bar/plate/rod stock and cut to length.

recipe_def.assumptions: Local steel route using carbothermal iron reduction, basic refining, and hot rolling; energy/time are best-guess placeholders.
recipe_def.notes: Replaces import placeholder for general steel stock feed used across machining and fabrication.

recipe_def.assumptions: Pig iron to steel ingot via refining to billet/slab then casting to ingot.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for steel ingot v0

steps.notes: Heat steel ingot or billet to rolling temperature (1100-1250C)
Hot roll to plate or sheet thickness with multiple passes

recipe_def.assumptions: Steel plate/sheet production from steel ingots via hot rolling. Plate is >6mm thick, sheet is <6mm. Pickling or cold rolling can be added for improved surface finish and dimensional control. QA inspection omitted here to avoid circular dependency on finished_part.
recipe_def.notes: Steel plate and sheet stock for fabrication, structural components, and enclosures. Surface treatment not yet modeled explicitly.

steps.notes: Hot roll steel ingot into bar or billet shapes

recipe_def.assumptions: Semi-finished steel product from hot rolling of ingots. Standard stock sizes for machining and forging feedstock.
recipe_def.notes: Production of steel bar and billet stock from ingots. Processing time ~1.5 hours per kg. ~5% loss to scale and trim.

steps.notes: Convert ingot into 3mm steel sheet

recipe_def.assumptions: Assumes input ingot is steel and thickness target is 3mm.
recipe_def.notes: Initial production recipe for steel sheet (3mm) from steel ingot.
recipe_def.name: Recipe for steel sheet 3mm

steps.notes: Roll billet into bar stock

inputs.notes: Steel billet for rolling into bar stock

recipe_def.assumptions: Local production path; placeholder; replace with detailed BOM and routing as needed.
recipe_def.notes: Converted from import_stub to a local production path using the existing rolling process.

steps.notes: Draw steel rod stock to appropriate filler wire diameter
Spool wire, inspect for defects, package for use

recipe_def.assumptions: Steel filler wire drawn from rod stock to standard diameters for welding and brazing applications.
recipe_def.notes: Basic filler wire for joining operations. Can be used for both welding and brazing depending on composition.

steps.notes: Cut steel plate or sheet stock into rough parts for downstream machining/forming

recipe_def.assumptions: Generic cutting path; downstream finishing handled in later recipes for specific parts. 5% material loss from cutting operations.
recipe_def.notes: Produce cut_parts from steel plate or sheet stock using basic cutting operations; includes sawing, shearing, or plasma cutting.
Roughly machine 2 kg of cut_parts into machined_part_raw

steps.notes: Hot forge hex heads on bolt blanks and upset nut blanks using dies
Cut external threads on bolts (M6-M12) and tap internal threads in nuts using lathes and tapping machines
Stamp flat washers and lock washers from steel sheet stock using progressive dies
Heat treat bolts and lock washers for hardness and spring properties (austenitizing, quenching, tempering)
Inspect heat-treated fasteners for hardness and dimensional checks
Sort fasteners by size (M6, M8, M10, M12), count, and kit into organized container

recipe_def.assumptions:
Complete fastener manufacturing from steel stock to finished kit. Process integrates:
- Hot forging for head formation (hex heads on bolts, upset blanks for nuts)
- Thread cutting via single-point turning (bolts) and tapping (nuts)
- Sheet metal stamping for washer production
- Heat treatment for strength and hardness
- Final inspection and kitting

Input materials: 2.0 kg steel stock (1.0 kg bar/billet, 1.0 kg sheet)
Output: 1.0 kg complete fastener kit per BOM specification
Scrap rate: ~50% from machining chips and stamping waste (conservative placeholder)
recipe_def.notes:
Six-step recipe for fastener_kit_medium production.

Kit composition per bom_fastener_kit_medium_v0:
- 720g hex bolts M6-M12 in various lengths (76 pieces total)
- 180g hex nuts M6-M12 (135 pieces total)
- 75g flat washers M6-M12 (135 pieces total)
- 30g lock washers M6-M12 (60 pieces total)
Total: ~366 fasteners, 1.0 kg net weight

Manufacturing process details:
1. Forging: Form hex heads on bolt blanks, upset nut blanks for adequate thread engagement
2. Threading: Cut external threads on bolts (dies or single-point), tap nuts (spiral point taps)
3. Washer stamping: Progressive die stamps flat and lock washers from sheet
4. Heat treatment: Quench and temper bolts to grade 8.8 equivalent, harden lock washers
5. Inspection: Verify hardness and dimensional checks
6. Kitting: Sort by size, verify counts, package in compartmented container

Total time: ~8 hours (primarily sequential, some parallel opportunity for washers)
References detailed specification in design/memos/fastener_kit_specification.md
Most commonly used fastener kit in the KB (107 BOMs reference this item)
